channel.title: New Gaming PC
channel.description:
I've been wanting a gaming PC for about 4 years now; I finally have a job, so I would like to start saving money every paycheck, which will eventually add up for a gaming PC. I've been looking at several and I'm willing to go up to $800 for one. I've found one that I personally like: http://www.ibuypower.com/Store/Ship_Out_Next_Business_Day_AMD_FX_4-Core
Does this seem like a good computer to game on? (With this I'd like to play games on decent quality without lag whilst also being able to record the game-play with FRAPS)

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @pitchblac23 pitchblac23
item.description:
@pitchblac23 wrote:

After reading this entire thread no one has gotten to help the op here in his/her question on acquiring a 800$ limit Gaming Computer. Who cares if its building, or assembling the computer its all the same to starting people i should know no college training and i still love putting one together. New egg, or Tigerdirect will offer great deals on preassembled computers, and also on parts for building/assembling your own, or just for upgrades. A lot of the other poster do have valid points if you can put a square block in a square hole then go for assembling/building your own just make sure to look if the motherboard will support something example (ddr ram will not work with ddr3). If you don’t quite feel comfortable with taking on this task look on YouTube or forums. There’s a lot of info on doing this on Google its quite easy I assembled/built 3 comps so far working on another as im typing this. Don’t get frustrated with looking at parts and thinking if i get all this and i cant put this together then i have failed im sure there’s a place in your town that will assemble/build it for you at a cost.

and if you really want a flame war amds are crap :D. 01 pen4 3.0 4g ddr with 9400gt nvid (my first comp i built/assembled) had 2 friends bring me there amd with over heating and bug problems was able to get them fixed. Mind you the comps they built/assembled where x2-x3 better then my own and they had 2-3 more buildings/assembling of different computer one had even went to college for computer tech. Amds will be cheap and going on a budget there ideal i just don’t like them my pen4 is still going today no problems but my hdds had 3 with clicks of deaths. Google will be your newest buddy if your looking to build/assemble your first computer took me 4 days to get that pen4 going but hey i did it and <3ed it

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

newegg.com

Computer Parts, Laptops, Electronics, and More - Newegg.com

Providing computer parts and hardware, hard drives, cameras and software as well as electronics, tools, appliances, sporting goods, jewelry, watches, gaming, and much more. With fast-shipping! Newegg shopping upgraded ™

The piece of shit I’m using right now I, “built”, or whatever terminology you want us to use in your thread. It’s running a AMD Phenom II X4. Possibly the nicest part on it… I have a six-core sitting on my desk, because the MOBO I was going to install as an upgrade cracked when I lifted up the gate to put the CPU in… Just one of the hard ships of putting a computer together on you’re own.

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:17, topic:456370”][quote author=Jaxus link=topic=559309.msg4089327#msg4089327 date=1346179335]Also, building a computer and putting a puzzle together is the worst comparison you could ever use.
[/quote]

you don’t BUILD a computer you ASSEMBLE it, the terminology that engineers use is different from common-usage terminology

and it’s a perfect analogy and you would know this if you had even taken any steps to looking at what is required to assemble a computer, the hardest part of building a computer is routing the cables because the rest of it is basically “connect this male sata connector into this female one” and you’re done, I’m willing to bet a 10 year old could build a pc if they had the patience for it[/quote]
That’s why everyone else in this thread has referred to it as building. Please just stop posting.

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Jaxus Jaxus
item.description:
@Jaxus wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:12, topic:456370”][quote author=Jaxus link=topic=559309.msg4088813#msg4088813 date=1346121429]
I didn’t even say computer engineering. I said engineering of the computer, and the definition of engineering is:
The branch of science and technology concerned with the design, building, and use of engines, machines, and structures
[/quote]

assembling pre-built pre-designed computer parts is not engineering, it is a glorified lego set with more instructions “how-tos” than an actual lego set

if you can solve this puzzle, you can assemble a computer[/quote]
Can we please get off the debate about engineering? It does involve building machines and a computer is a machine. Also, building a computer and putting a puzzle together is the worst comparison you could ever use.

Read full topic

a pc repair technician will never be called a computer engineer… also, no one in their right mind with a comp. eng. degree would work for 7-15/hr

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Loveandpower, post:1, topic:456703”]Not necessarily 100% true either t4. Any job depends on locations, population, job duties, and etc.

A lot of times a company will also title a position one thing, but have it have the duties of something lower. This way, they get a more qualified member at alower pay-rate generally speaking.

For example: Different system administrator levels/Sys Admin “leads” instead of “director” even though they actually have the same duties.[/quote]
what does that have to do with this situation? there’s a HUGE difference between the two types of jobs… you have no idea what you’re talking about.

edit: to put it into perspective, you’re basically calling a mechanical engineer and a mechanic the same job.

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“the elve age, post:7, topic:456370”][quote author=t4 link=topic=559309.msg4088380#msg4088380 date=1346092200]

build yourself and research the parts on newegg

I have no experience in computer engineering whatsoever; I’m definitely not going to buy the parts separately (even though is is a lot cheaper)and attempt to build it myself. With my luck, I’d end up frying the motherboard or corrupting the hard drive.

The only reason I want to buy one is so I can convert my current one into a project so I can learn the basics of engineering of the computer.

building a machine from existing parts isn’t computer engineering lol
[/quote]Computer engineering is a discipline that integrates several fields of electrical engineering and computer science required to develop computer systems.

I believe it is. I wouldn’t say building a computer from existing parts is common knowledge.[/quote]
anyone who is a computer engineer would be greatly offended at your definition. a computer engineer works designing hardware: CPUs and the like; they also can write drivers. they don’t assemble computers rofl.

entry level IT people build machines. they get paid at most 30k/yr. computer engineers out of university can score 80-120k easily.

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @gothic_queen casey.
item.description:
@gothic_queen wrote:

reddit

Planning on building a computer but need some advice? This is the place to ask!...

Planning on building a computer but need some advice? This is the place to ask! /r/buildapc is a community-driven subreddit dedicated to custom...

reddit

Tailor-designed builds. • r/buildapcforme

A subreddit dedicated to helping those looking to assemble their own PC without having to spend weeks researching and trying to find the right...

I had no knowledge on how to build a PC but knew I wanted to do it because it’s honestly a fun task and is somewhat of an accomplishment knowing you built it. With advice from a few people from reddit and irc I was able to build a great set up for a lot loss than buying it prebuilt.

Hell, if you don’t even want to build it you can pay me 800$ and I’ll do it for you

Read full topic

item.title: New Gaming PC
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

The hardest part about building a computer is getting a case with proper cooling and power supply stuff (from experience anyway). It’s very hard to buy incompatible parts if you’re looking for high-end parts. Newegg will show all the specs of the hardware you’re buying so you really don’t have to worry about risks or not knowing something about the parts.

Read full topic

I’ve been wanting a gaming PC for about 4 years now; I finally have a job, so I would like to start saving money every paycheck, which will eventually add up for a gaming PC. I’ve been looking at several and I’m willing to go up to $800 for one. I’ve found one that I personally like:
